title: 109_s2205
content: The Act may be cited as the "Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal Land Conveyance Act of 2006". This Act pertains to the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal. In this section, key definitions include the Blunt Reservoir feature, the Commission, and nonpreferential lease parcel related to the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal. The Pierre Canal feature is part of the Oahe Unit, James Division, authorized by the Act of August 3, 1968. It is a nonpreferential lease parcel for use in connection with the Blunt Reservoir feature or the Pierre Canal feature. The term "preferential leaseholder" refers to a person or descendant who held a lease on a preferential lease parcel as of January 1, 2001. The term "preferential lease parcel" is a land purchased by the Secretary for use in connection with the Blunt Reservoir feature or the Pierre Canal feature. A "parcel" refers to land purchased by the Secretary for the Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal features, considered a preferential lease parcel as of January 1, 2001. The Secretary is the Secretary of the Interior, and the State refers to South Dakota or its successor. An "unleased parcel" is also defined. The Blunt Reservoir feature is deauthorized, and an unleased parcel is defined as land not under lease purchased for the Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal features. The State of South Dakota or its successor may accept land and obligations as part of conveyances. As part of conveyances, the State may agree to accept the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal features in "as is" condition, along with any liabilities arising from ownership, operation, or maintenance of these features. This includes obligations related to expired easements or other rights associated with the features. The Commission will act as the agent for the Secretary in administering purchase options for preferential leaseholders. Outstanding obligations related to expired easements or rights will be binding upon the State. Oil, gas, mineral, and other rights will transfer to the State through conveyances or sales. Oil, gas, mineral, and other rights will transfer to the State subject to existing reservations and permits. The conveyance to the State under subsection (d)(5) or (e) is subject to reservations by the United States and conditions specified in the Act of May 19, 1948 for wildlife conservation purposes. A preferential leaseholder has an option to purchase from the Secretary or the Commission. A preferential leaseholder has the option to purchase the preferential lease parcel from the Secretary or the Commission. The purchase can be made on specific terms, including a cash purchase amount. The preferential leaseholder can purchase the preferential lease parcel from the Secretary or the Commission at a price determined by subtracting ten percent from the parcel's value. The preferential leaseholder can purchase the parcel with 10% down and the rest paid over 30 years at 3% interest. If the parcel is under $10,000, it must be purchased in cash. The option to purchase must be exercised within 5 years of the Act's enactment. The preferential leaseholder has 5 years after the Act's enactment to exercise the purchase option. They can continue leasing the parcel under the same terms until then. The value of the lease parcel is based on its fair market value for agricultural purposes. The value of a preferential lease parcel is determined by its fair market value for agricultural purposes, less 25 percent, in accordance with the Uniform Appraisal Standards for Federal Land Acquisition. Any disputes over the fair market value shall be resolved according to section 2201.4 of title 43, Code of Federal Regulations. If a preferential leaseholder fails to purchase a parcel within the specified period, the Secretary will offer to convey the parcel to the State of South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks for wildlife habitat mitigation purposes. The South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks will use proceeds from land sales to mitigate wildlife habitat lost due to the Pick-Sloan project. Funds will be deposited in the Treasury as miscellaneous funds and made available, subject to appropriations, to establish a trust fund for paying county taxes on lands received by the Department. Nonpreferential lease parcels and unleased parcels will be conveyed as per the Act. The Secretary will offer to convey nonpreferential lease parcels and unleased parcels of the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal to the South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks for wildlife habitat mitigation within a year of the Act's enactment. The South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks will use land exchanges for nonpreferential lease parcels and unleased parcels at Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal to mitigate wildlife habitat lost due to the Pick-Sloan project. The South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks will exchange land for nonpreferential lease parcels and unleased parcels at Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal to mitigate wildlife habitat lost due to the Pick-Sloan project. Priority is given to current lessees and adjoining landowners for the exchanges. The United States reserves a perpetual easement for water conveyance structures over the Pierre Canal feature in exchange for land. The government will not be held liable upon conveyance of any parcel under this Act. Upon conveyance of any parcel under this Act, the United States will not be liable for damages arising from any act, omission, or occurrence related to the parcel, except for negligence committed before the conveyance. This section does not increase the liability of the United States under the Federal Tort Claims Act. During the interim period, the Secretary will lease parcels under existing terms. Parcel descriptions must be provided within 180 days. The Secretary will provide legal descriptions of lease parcels within 180 days. Archeological collections from specific features will be transferred to the South Dakota State Historical Society. Archeological and cultural items from the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal features will be given to the South Dakota State Historical Society. $750,000 is authorized for implementing the Act, with additional funds for expenses incurred by the Secretary, Commission, and State Department of Game, Fish, and Parks.
